Fields.DialogueText: How goes the painting?
It goes nowhere.
Bored already?
No, ideas come. Then I realize they've all been painted before. It's pointless.
Eliot said "Immature poets imitate; mature poets steal."
What do you mean?
Copy the work you admire. Learn from it.
But I'll never be as good as they are.
These comparisons are a trap. Find your voice and share it with the world. No one else can do that.
I will think on this further. Are you an artist?

Fields.MenuText: There's art in everything. Even commanding a ship.
I have a handmade collection of knots. Does that count?
I enjoy splatter painting. Morganas are my medium and the ocean my canvas.

Fields.DialogueText: So is it a tragedy or a comedy?
It does knot.
Is such drama required to be a capitaine or do you cultivate it for leisure?
Hold that thought. A Morgana approaches.
My favorite - the art of war.
@BATTLE
You have a brooding look today. Is angst taught in officer school or just an affectation to gain attention?
That depends. Is it working?
Not at all.
You wound me.
So easily? They promised me an instrument of war. A shark that would wreak havoc across the high seas.
I'm a sea lion. Looking for a warm rock to flop on so I can sun my belly and count my whiskers, while the ocean tickles my flippers.
I've been cheated. I should throw you back and catch a better fish.
First, you need better bait.
Non, we French know the art of attraction. Why should I keep you?

Fields.MenuText: If I left, you would miss me.
You might catch a blubbering whale, spouting water on your decks and lumbering in circles.
My replacement might interpret naval policies on stocking the galley more... literally.

Fields.DialogueText: Then I must improve my aim. You'll have to do for now.
That sounds terrible. Better the devil I know.
A chance I can't take. You do have imagination, I'll give you that.
Thanks for the vote of confidence.
Off the rock, you lazy beast. A Morgana approaches.
The genius of my leisure. As I rest, my enemy comes to me.
A most generous perspective.
Now I'm generous. See, you can't decide whether you love or hate me.
@BATTLE
Honestly, Captaine. First I find you lazing around outside and now I find you in here stuffing your face?
Will you deny a sailor the simple pleasure of a well-cooked meal? Come and join me.
If I don't, who would clear your throat when you choke on your third helping?
Only Paris could wound my heart and stomach with one blow.
I only say these things to help you, Capitaine. I hope you can see that.
Don't worry. I may not be as energetic as you, but I can at least see how much better off I am with you by my side.
Well... Good.
The great Paris is speechless? If a simple compliment is all it takes, I may start dishing them out more often.
You certainly are a master at dishing things out. When is helping number four?
Touché. What say we work off some of this food by tackling some Morganas!
That's better!
@BATTLE
My eyes are sending images my brain cannot understand. What on earth are you carrying around? It looks like a sleeveless leotard.
Would that be so strange? The French invented the leotard, after all.
Why does that not surprise me?
Oui. The great French acrobat, Jules Léotard. It made him quite popular with the ladies.
You're trying to attract women?
Non. I am preparing for my Savate practice.
Boxe française? Wasn't that in the Summer Olympics?
Yes, the 1924 exhibition in Paris.

Fields.MenuText: The focus striking fits, but I would not have guessed you were a boxer.
You're full of surprises.
Well, then. When we next find a Morgana I'll catapult you onto their deck.

Fields.DialogueText: Non? You imagine me a helpless waif?
Here is another surprise.
The guns are more practical, and I don't want blood on my uniform.
Stop--
Kicking--
Me! That's an order!
Your defense is pitiful.
Aren't you my defense?
And what happens when I am unable to face down a Morgana and protect you at the same time? Will you roll over and die?
I'm sure I can manage.
I'm not so sure, to be quite honest... Let's put it to the test.
@BATTLE
Paris, remember your conversation with Birts?
I can hardly forget. What an insult.
Yes, that all degenerated rather quickly - but he said he was curious, and I take him at his word.
Have you a point, or do you just enjoy the sound of your voice?
He is interested in learning from you.
Did I not instruct him?
It sounded to me more like an assault.
Oui, enfin. I am a battleship, not a school.
Nonetheless, in a mixed fleet, you are also to represent France.
Perhaps, but I am not trained as a diplomat.
I don't know... why did France agree to cede Québec to Britain?
That is a more complicated question than you seem to think. The easiest answer? We wanted the sugar of Guadeloupe more.
So sugar can be worth more than fighting? Interesting. Perhaps consider that when you talk to Birts again.
You certainly take the long way around.
I have knowledge of tactics other than the full frontal assault.
You dislike the full frontal?
But you are a historian, just by virtue of being who you are. If I were to ask you about the Treaty of Paris...?
1763, you mean? What about it?
You would be doing me a great service, Paris. Does it make you feel less subservient if you think of this as a favor and less of an order?
... It might.
Then please, could you talk with the Brits for me?
I suppose.
Good. And, just so we're clear, this was only a favor in theory.
Perhaps the protection from the Morganas I promised was also only in theory.
@BATTLE
I've heard the fleet is forming a flotilla to pursue the Morganas.
They're considering it, among many other options.
We must volunteer.
It's not a question of volunteering. They select who they see fit.
Convince them we are fit.

Fields.MenuText: Perhaps you've heard of the chain of command? They give orders. I carry them out.
They are aware of our capabilities.
You mean overstate our capabilities?

Fields.DialogueText: You are not always so passive.
So they will choose us?
You doubt my readiness?
Why do you want to be in the flotilla?
I am made to attack. French battleships belong in the front.
So that's what this is about. Our service record is beyond reproach. You've represented La Royale with--
Others have done more.
This isn't a contest, and - in case you haven't noticed - our current duties aren't unimportant, and they're certainly not lacking in action.
What mission? This is a patrol! We can patrol anywhere to the same effect! We cannot just turn them away from random stretches of coastline - we must seek them out and destroy them!
Everyone in the fleet understands that. Command is not timid...
A Morgana approaches now. With the initiative, as usual.
Enough. Focus on your job. We'll discuss this later.
@BATTLE
No offense, but I don't particularly want to throw our current mission into disarray just because you have a vague hope we'll find more enemy battleships off the coast of West Africa.
Capitaine, I am holding back as much as I can, but we should pursue.
Proceed with caution.
@BATTLE
Capitaine, we must be more aggressive.
More aggressive? We've hardly been sitting idle.
Even British naval doctrine is clear that offensive action is necessary to seize the initiative.
Yes, but it also says we must not take the first step without considering the last.
Right. Command will put us to our best use based on their strategy.
Our best use is in the flotilla destroying Morganas.
Paris, stand to attention. You are not yourself. I begin to suspect the Morganas have begun to influence you.
Quoi? Non. Madness.
Really? It's not like you to demand we rush headlong into the Morgana fog and see what happens. You've been acting strange for a while now. What has brought this on?
I've instructed the fleet that we must soon return to port. Use this time wisely. Paint, cook, practice violence in your leotard, do whatever you have to - but regain some perspective.
We are to repair and resupply. Before departure I will report.
If I have to inform Command our Belle is erratic and unfit for battle, their next thought will not be the flotilla. Understood?
Oui, Capitaine.
Dismissed.
How was shore leave?
Good. Except for Birts' drunken acapella version of "God Save the King." My ears may never recover.
I'm sorry I missed it.
Don't be. What about you? You seem to be in better spirits.
I'm feeling a little conflicted, Capitaine. You won't tell the fleet, will you? At least not until I've figured things out.

Fields.MenuText: I must inform them of the tactic, but I'll say you detected it and resisted.
Our superiors have to know that we suspect a new kind of threat.
This will remain between captain and Belle.

Fields.DialogueText: Merci, Capitaine. I appreciate your support.
If you think that is best. I fear they'll never trust me again.
Merci, Capitaine. I appreciate your discretion.
It's not like you mutinied, Paris. I'm proud to serve with you, and I'll say it to anyone who asks.
Merci beaucoup. Oh, and I did take your advice! Look at my new painting!
An eclair? I suppose that makes sense.
It's good to be back at sea. The ocean sings to us.
Of what?
She sings of our virtue. Brave sailors fighting for humanity.
Then let's put the past behind us and not let her down.
And it is good to be back by your side, Capitaine.
I feel the same way. I must have put on several kilos without your scolding.
We will have to have dinner together every day from now on, it seems. To monitor your diet, that is...
Let's work up an appetite on these Morganas.
@BATTLE
Birtie, after the war is over, you must visit the French countryside.
Indeed?
Oui, it's beautiful. Your wife will love it. You can rent a nice villa, relax, and enjoy the world's best wine.
The English countryside is quite nice too, you know. My wife enjoys gingerbread houses and the country lanes of the Cotswolds.
Why are English manors so stuffy and formal?
They're sturdy. Respectable. Proper homes for proper families.
Proper. Such an English word. Must you always be proper? Don't you ever kick up your heels and relax?
The French villa says "Bonjour. Life is good. Enjoy some wine and relax on the patio."
The English manor says, "Sir, button up your shirt. Straighten your tie. Tea will be served in the drawing room at eleven. Please do be on time."
We may not philander in the streets with our knickers out, but we know how to have a good time.
Captain, you've seen the world. Which do you prefer? France or England?

Fields.MenuText: England.
France.
Switzerland.

Fields.DialogueText: Impossible. You must properly tour France under my instruction. Then you will understand.
You see?
Neutral? How boring.
That is the beauty of the world. There's someplace for everyone. Now let's focus on the task at hand.
We'd better. Morganas are closing in quickly.
General quarters!
@BATTLE
Paris, where did this cat come from?
Mreooooooowwww!
Aww, a Chartreux. She yowls because you hold her like a sack of potatoes. Give her to me.
Where...
She is cute. Look, a tag. Lili, it says. Bonjour, Lili. Paris has you now.
Have you fed her?
No, I haven't fed her! I want to know...
Come, Lili, we will go to the galley. I'll get you some milk. Maybe some tuna.
Would you like that, little fur face? Yes, Mama knows you would...
Paris!
Stop yelling, you maniac. I'm right here.
Where did the cat come from?
France, obviously.
Yes, I know that. Who brought it aboard?
She is a stowaway.
You're saying she just scampered on deck?
I don't know. I'll ask her after she drinks her milk.
You can talk to cats too?
I'm a Belle, not a cat psychic.
What next?
A Morgana. Must you always tempt fate? I'll see to Lili.
Yes, secure the cat. I'm glad we have our priorities straight.
Don't listen to the mean Capitaine. Mama will take care of you.
Meow!
@BATTLE
Hello... oh my. Is that a cat?
She's certainly not an elephant. Her name is Lili.
Does the Captain know?
Yes, the Capitaine brought her to me. I'm not sure if I'll get to keep her, though.
I'd imagine not, seeing as this is a battleship in wartime!
Settle down, Birtie. What is it with you officers? You can fight off the Morganas, but one kitten and you come unglued.
I'm allergic to cats.
That's all right, Lili doesn't want you anyway. Right, Lili?
She... she's coming right towards me. Back, you!
Curious. Cats are always attracted to the person that doesn't want them.
Stay back! I'll see you later, Paris.
An executive officer, running from a cat. Just when you think you've seen it all.
There you are. I take it the beast here has scared off poor Birts?
Lili is not a "beast," she is a cat. First Cat Lili, reporting to duty!
Meow.

Fields.MenuText: I may vomit.
You might want to hold off on getting her fitted for a uniform.
I'm not entirely hostile, but I will not be swayed by cuteness.

Fields.DialogueText: I had an idea...
I bet you do, but that's the alarm. And she ran under your bunk. Lovely. Secure her and get ready for battle.
@BATTLE
Shush. My favorite part is coming up.
Let me guess. Cole Porter?
Shush!
I'm the captain. You really can't be shushing me.
You're ruining the song.
Anything goes! He sang it himself.
You're impossible. What do you want?
About the cat...
Lili.
Yes, Lili. You realize can't just bring whatever animal we want aboard, right?
Would you have me throw her overboard?

Fields.MenuText: Yes. Would you, please?
I'll do it.
No. You can keep her for now, but there are conditions.

Fields.DialogueText: I do hope you are joking.
You must be joking! You will do no such thing. You have not yet seen me kick in anger.
Merci! You have a good heart.
Get a cage from engineering that can be fastened to your bunk. In rough seas or during operations, she stays in the cage.
Out of the cage, she must be kept out of the crew's hair as they work. Got it?
Oui.
This will be a fascinating story for my children.
How you spared a cat?
No, how I lost my command over a cat.
Do not fret, Capitaine. I will protect Lili with my life. You will see.
Speaking of which...
A Morgana is in the area.
Time to play cat and mouse.
Not your best work.
@BATTLE
Is the beast gone?
Lili remains, if that is what you mean.
Outrageous. This... this is just not as it should be, Captain.
At least she's not a penguin.
Pardon me?
Never mind. She's here now, doubtless terrorizing the rats in the hold. Try and keep up.
This must not stand.
Birtie, stop being so melodramatic. She's just a kitten.
The road to hell is paved with good intentions. And kittens.
Ridiculous.
It's me or her.
You or Lili?
Choose.

Fields.MenuText: Start swimming, Birts. Good luck.
I'm the Captain. I'll make the ultimatums around here.
I choose you both.

Fields.DialogueText: You chose THE CAT?!
This is too much.
Both? That wasn't an option.
Ships' mascots have a fine maritime history, and I have every faith that Lili will live up to it. The matter's settled.
In fact, it's probably best to consider the First Cat your ranking officer for the foreseeable future. It should save a lot of fuss.
... Captain, I will be in my quarters.
Can you believe him?
He'll get over it. Sometimes the worst battles are the ones we create for ourselves.
He won't make trouble for you with Command, will he?
No. Lili's not the only cat on the high seas. Besides, he needs my recommendation, and he won't want to be remembered as a rat.
You know what cats do to rats. Speaking of rats, a Morgana is due east.
Claws out. Time to hunt.
@BATTLE
Anything to report, Birts?
I don't know.
You don't know?!
I assumed you would ask the cat.
Do tell: why would I ask Lili?
Given her elevated status, I assumed status reports to be part of her duties.
I see. Birtwistle, your duties remain unchanged.
What exactly are the duties of the First Cat?
She is in charge of all feline operations, of course.
What feline operations?
The deployment and coordination of feline resources. Such as cat patrols.
Cat patrols, you say?
Should I allow the rats uncontested access to our food?
Of course not, but... there are other countermeasures.
Yes, a ship with no First Cat would have to settle for those countermeasures. Fortunately, we do not have that problem.
Can I count on Lili's recommendation?
Recommendation?
As my superior officer. I'm not familiar with the protocol in this situation.
Oh. I'd say you have some groundwork to do.

Fields.MenuText: Sorry, Birts, I was out of line. Your ultimatum wound me up. I apologize.
Only kidding. I'm sorry I hurt your feelings, but try to lighten up.
Give Lili a toy. You want to get the relationship off on the right paw.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you.
Don't make a joke of this ship. I take my responsibilities seriously.
You go too far. Outrageous!
The First Cat has been demoted. Now you both report to me.
The alarm!
@BATTLE
Captain, do you see that?
The flashing red light? Hard to miss.
It feels... odd.
Is it a ship?
Perhaps. It's difficult to see clearly through the rain.
Could it be an improvised flare? A ship in distress?
Something's not right.
A Morgana trap?

Fields.MenuText: We will approach, ready for anything. Call general quarters.
It's not a tactic they're known for, but they're unpredictable.
You're afraid of flares now?

Fields.DialogueText: Aye, Captain.
I don't like it.
No, Captain, only prudently cautious.
Look on the bright side. I'm sure it isn't a cat.
There is that, at least.
@BATTLE
Capitaine, you must learn self-defense.
Nonsense, I was taught to fight in the-- oof! Why did you kick me in the stomach?
Why do you not use these fighting skills you speak of?
That was a sneak attack. I wasn't ready. OOF! Paris! In the face?
You are ready now?
I do not see why this is necessary. Oof! Paris!
You are an officer. You must be able to defend yourself.
Fine, fine. Just stop kicking me.
Put your arms like this. I will kick like so. When I do, step back like this. See?
Yes, you will kick, and then-- oof!
You said oui, but you did not move.
Paris, have you ever taught self-defense before?
I usually focus more on offense.

Fields.MenuText: Then let's focus on offense.
Your teaching skills need some work.
The pace of your class is a bit too aggressive.

Fields.DialogueText: Oui, you are very offensive.
Oui, my teaching is the problem. What else could explain your hopeless lack of skill?
Perhaps the pace of your learning is too slow.
Kick me.
Oof! You kicked back.
Do you suppose your enemy will just stand there while you--
AAAAAAAAA!
Capitaine. You tackled me.
Yes. Offense, you see.
I was making a point.
Perhaps your defense needs work.
Are you planning on getting up, or are you so tired you must lay on me until you recover?
Right!
Honestly, Capitaine, if you wanted to lie with me, all you had to do was ask.
What would your answer have been...?
Non.
I figured.
Maybe if it were a special occassion. Someone's birthday perhaps, or an anniversary. I may make an exception.
Interesting...
Pick your tongue up off the floor, Capitaine, a Morgana approaches. You and Lili are in safe hands.
@BATTLE
Captain, you look stiff. Are you all right?
There must be a storm approaching. These old joints, you know?
Is that a bruise on your jaw?
No, just a trick of the light. Report, XO.
All systems normal. Morganas have been reported in our area of operation.
Good, maybe our patrol will flush some rabbits.
Rabbits? Are you concussed?
Of course not, don't be ridiculous. Do you have a twin?
No.
Who's that beside you?
No one is beside me.
Never mind. Hello, Paris.
Bonjour. I wasn't too hard on you, was I, Capitaine?
My.

Fields.MenuText: What do you mean? I'm fine.
It's not like that, Birtwistle. We had a minor sparring session.
Too hard? I think I was too easy on you. Next time we will push the pace.

Fields.DialogueText: Good, I was barely kicking.
Euh, non, Birtie, I was just kicking the Capitaine around my quarters.
Oui? That is a relief. I mistook your effort for full speed.
Right. Let's focus on the task at hand.
Prudent, Capitaine. A Morgana approaches from the west.
@BATTLE
I know you wanted to talk to me, Birtie. We can do it as soon as we defeat these Morganas.
@BATTLE
I don't know what games you and the Captain play, nor do I want to. But Paris, you must not beat up the Captain.
I didn't beat the Capitaine. I was teaching self-defense.
I saw little evidence of defense.
Oui. The lack of coordination was surprising.
Yes, well, for the Captain I'm sure it was embarrassing. Can you cage the beast, please?
This is Lili's playtime. I would think not knowing self-defense would be more embarrassing than a training session.
The Captain must present a strong image of leadership. That is difficult to do when used as a punching bag--
I only kicked.
I'm allergic to cats. I really must insist--
I was trying to help.
Yes, but we need the Captain in working order. We are here to support our commanding officer.
There really isn't much threat of hand-to-hand combat on a battleship.
Perhaps not. At least I am here to protect the Capitaine.
I'm sure that is a relief to the Captain. I'll leave you both to it.
Birts, you're swollen like a pufferfish. You didn't spar with Paris, did you?
No, Captain, the cat.
You sparred with Lili?
I'm allergic to the cat.
That's unfortunate. Why go to her cabin, then?
Paris and I had a matter to discuss.
Not another France versus Britain debate, I hope?
Another matter. It ended satisfactorily.
Glad to hear it. Where is Paris?
Here, Capitaine.
Goodness, you're like a genie. The genie and the pufferfish. What a story.
I haven't heard of it. How does it begin?

Fields.MenuText: A captain gazes from the bridge of a battleship, steely-eyed and wary.
A captain surveys the horizon and is suddenly startled by a giant pufferfish.
A captain calls for a genie, who suddenly appears and asks questions.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm bored already.
Sounds fishy.
What does the genie ask?
Well--
Capitaine, we have Morganas running south of us in a parallel course.
Move to intercept. Sound the alarm.
@BATTLE
I've been practicing my guard. Look--
Oui. That is... an improvement.
Kick me.
Capitaine, I would love to, but I'm in the middle of a project.
What project?
I am working on a variation of the eclair.
Oh. So no kicking then?
Sorry, Capitaine.
Does this mean painting is on the back burner?
I do not burn my paintings!
No, it's a phrase. I ask if your eclair project means you aren't painting?
Non. I lack inspiration. What do you think I should paint?

Fields.MenuText: Lili.
A self-portrait.
The Eiffel Tower.

Fields.DialogueText: Oui. That is a good idea, but she will not hold still.
I suppose I could. I'll need to find a suitable mirror.
A bit of a cliche, non?
Every subject has its unique challenges.
A Morgana is approaching.
Then let's challenge them!
@BATTLE
You look deep in thought, Paris. A new book, I presume.
Indeed. The Mask of Innocence, by François Mauriac.
Sounds fascinating. I've never heard of it, personally.
Well, it details the life of a crazy person. To be honest, for the first few chapters, I assumed it was your autobiography.

Fields.MenuText: Come now. I only seem crazy.
Which of my personalities are you studying?
I didn't know you were so interested in my thoughts.

Fields.DialogueText: That is a relief.
I was only joking, Capitaine, but this does explain a lot...
A Belle must know her capitaine, non?
I wonder what book would be best to understand you further.
If you can't already read me like a book, Capitaine, we have a lot more work to do.
I can parse the words that litter your expressions, but I'm still working on reading between the lines.
As titillating as your literary metaphors may be, Capitaine, I'm afraid we have company.
Let's teach them a lesson.
@BATTLE
First Cat, report!
Meow!
She is well, but feisty this morning.
Kitty wants to play? Yes. Yes, she does.
I would not advise that. She--
Ow!
Oui. Lili bites when she is in a mood.
Why is it that visiting you so often leads to injury?
Perhaps you are too quick to let your guard down.

Fields.MenuText: Next time I will bring an armed guard.
Yes, foolish me, trusting my Belle with my safety.
I came here to relax, not fight for my survival.

Fields.DialogueText: I think it would be crowded. Perhaps just keep your wits about you.
Come, Capitaine. Don't be sore. Euh, poor choice of words.
Relax, then. I will protect you from the big bad kitten.
If even a cat is enough to wound you, what hope is there against the Morganas?
I would not let down my guard so easily unless the Morganas were as cute as Lili here.
Again. You fail to take anything I say seriously. Truly, it is becoming quite distressing.
Whoa, Paris. I thought we were just having fun.
Fun has its place even in war, but you choose truly perplexing times for frolicking. You'll frolic yourself into an early grave at this rate!
Paris. Why don't you take a minute to collect yourself?
I will handle the Morganas. Look after Lili.
@BATTLE
Paris, what's come over you? I doubt it's just the cat sending you into these episodes.
I have tried and tried to make you see sense, Capitaine.
What sense?
To fix your diet, to be more active, to learn self-defense.
Yes, and?
What will you do when I am not there to protect you?!
I see. So that's what this is about. And so Lili...?
If I cannot protect a cat, what hope do I have of protecting my capitaine? I would feel much more at ease if I knew you could at least throw a punch.
You don't have to worry about me, Paris.
Please. You couldn't block a single kick from me.
Maybe not. But I'm sure after we start regularly sparring in the early morning hours, I will pick things up.
You... Oui, Capitaine. I am not fond of teaching, but I can make an exception.
Morganas on approach. Please assist me!
@BATTLE
You know that's not what I--
Of course not. You're a battleship.
Paris, what are you drinking?
A Château de Goulaine Muscadet. One of France's oldest wines.
Muscadet, you say?
Care for a glass?

Fields.MenuText: Oui, merci.
No, thank you. I'd best keep my wits about me.
Another time.

Fields.DialogueText: I know Birts would be scandalized, but you should speak French more often, Capitaine.
Suit yourself. Perhaps that's for the best.
As you like.
How many bottles of wine do you have aboard, anyway?
Let's just say there are redundancies in case of torpedo attack.
Don't tell me more. It's probably better that I don't know.
Oui, plausible deniability.
It is nice to enjoy moments of respite like this.
Enjoy it while it lasts, Capitaine. Starting Monday, I plan on whipping you into shape.
Ooh, spicy.
A glutton for punishment, I see. I will make you eat those words.
I thought I was supposed to be on a diet.
Don't you worry. I plan on making those words be the ONLY thing you eat for the next week.
Ha! It's a date.
*ALARM*
Just when I was getting comfortable.
@BATTLE
What will you do after the war, Paris?
Once the enemies of France have been defeated, I might like to be a depot ship.
I didn't see that coming.
Imagine. A nice post off the Mediterranean coast, where I can expand the galley, stock fresh ingredients, and prepare wondrous meals for the fleet.
You won't miss the ocean?
We can still talk. The novelty of the open sea wears off after a few decades.
Smaller waves inland, too.
Oui. Fewer storms, less rain...
I see the sense of it. It's just hard to imagine the fierce battleship Paris domesticated.
I would not say domesticated. Just fighting battles in the galley.
Will you miss anything?
Oh, perhaps. Oui. I think... I... I shall miss... some of the crew. What will you miss?

Fields.MenuText: The rush of combat. Of knowing that your next few moments could be life or death.
The journey. Seeing the world, the freedom of the open horizon.
You.

Fields.DialogueText: How strange that the threat of death makes you feel alive.
Oui, the world is full of beauty.
Honestly, Captain, you... Oui, I shall miss you as well.
Anyway, enough chatter. Are you ready to begin your training?
As I'll ever be...
Don't look so down, Capitaine. I may have a reward for you if you complete my rigorous training course.
A reward you say?
Oui. It is your birthday, after all. Therefore, I will permit you what I promised earlier. I hope you remember.
What you... Oh! OH! But wait, it isn't my--
